column3: is a city in Miami-Dade County
column6: located  southwest of Downtown Miami. The United States Census Bureau estimates conducted in 2019 yielded the city had a population of 49
column7: 700. Coral Gables is a Mediterranean-themed planned community known for its affluent and historic character. It holds several zip codes consistently ranked among the wealthiest in the United States. It is also home to the University of Miami.

column1: Coral Gables was one of the first planned communities
column2: and its planning was based on the popular early twentieth century City Beautiful Movement. It is infamous for its strict zoning regulations. The city was developed by George Merrick during the Florida land boom of the 1920s. The city's architecture is almost entirely Mediterranean Revival style
column4: including the Coral Gables Congregational Church
column5: donated by Merrick. The domed Catholic Church of the Little Flower was built somewhat later
column6: in a similar Spanish Renaissance style. By 1926
column9: 000 ha) and had netted $150 million in sales
column10: with over $100 million spent on development.

column1: Merrick meticulously designed the downtown commercial district to be only four blocks wide and more than two miles (3 km) long. The main artery bisected the business district. Merrick could boast that every business in Coral Gables was less than a two-block walk. The city used to have an electric trolley system
column2: which was replaced by the popularity of modern automobiles
column3: but now a new free circulator trolley system
column5: runs down Ponce de León Boulevard.

column6: Coral Gables is known as the Fine Dining Capital of South Florida.

column1: Coral Gables is located at 25°43′42″N 80°16′16″W.
